docs.lead_paragraph: Trace amounts of a widely used farm chemical that some tests have shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals have been detected in apple juice and applesauce sold in supermarkets. Officials of the National Food Processors Association said last week that chemists from some of the group's 600 member companies had identified tiny amounts of the chemical, daminozide, in 73 samples of applesauce and 132 samples of apple juice. Officials of Gerber Products, the nation's largest maker of baby food, said the company's chemists had detected low levels of daminozide, which is sold under the trade name Alar, in samples of apple juice and applesauce. ''None of the samples tested showed levels that approached federally established limits,'' said John Whitlock, a Gerber spokesman.

headline.main: TINY TRACES OF SUSPECT CHEMICAL FOUND IN APPLE JUICE AND SAUCE
